title: On the Campaign Trail, Obama’s Hard to Find
authors: Carol E. Lee, Colleen Mccain Nelson
content:
At a rally for Democratic candidates filled with blistering attacks on Republicans , President Barack Obama trotted out lines from his successful 2008 campaign . “ Are you fired up ? ” he asked . “ Are you ready to go ? ” The crowd at a Philadelphia park , stretched out to the parking lot , chanted “ Yes we can ! ”
That was Oct. 10 , 2010 . Four years later , the contrast with Mr. Obama ’ s role in the current midterm campaign is stark , and it underscores the limited value the Democratic Party is placing on its leader this election .
On Thursday night , Mr. Obama was in the backyard of actress Gwyneth Paltrow ’ s Los Angeles home , speaking to a small group of wealthy donors far from the spotlight . His tone was far different than the “ Fired Up ! ” chant of the 2010 rally .
“ Democrats have many good qualities , but a congenital disease is , A : We get depressed too easily ; and B : We ’ re terrible at paying attention to midterm elections , ” Mr. Obama said .
No cameras were allowed at Ms. Paltrow ’ s event . No local Democratic candidates received a presidential shout-out .
Mr. Obama ’ s low-key appearance at Ms. Paltrow ’ s home wasn ’ t the exception this year : He has headlined no public campaign events this election cycle , and since Labor Day he has appeared in person with only two candidates—in the Democratic states of California and Illinois . By this point four years ago , Mr. Obama had led three rallies , and in the weeks since Labor Day he had held political events with five candidates , even with an approval rating of 47 % , according to the Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll at the time .
Now , with his approval at a low-water mark of 40 % , according to the Journal/NBC poll , the president has been relegated to fundraising and small , targeted photo-ops like one he did Thursday when he dropped by the Los Angeles campaign office of House candidate Ted Lieu .
Rep. Steve Israel of New York , the chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee , said he hoped Mr. Obama ’ s appearance with Mr. Lieu was “ a preview of similar engagements by the president . ”
“ We ’ d love to see more of that , ” Mr. Israel said .
The president ’ s campaign slate will pick up in coming weeks—the White House said Mr. Obama would appear at a Connecticut rally next week . But in some ways , the contrast between 2010 and 2014 is only going to become more evident .
Even though the fight for control of the Senate is the year ’ s top battle , administration officials say much of the president ’ s time on the campaign trail will be spent stumping for gubernatorial and House candidates . With Mr. Obama so unpopular in most states with close Senate races this fall , Democratic candidates are putting as much distance between themselves and the president as they can . At a newspaper editorial board meeting on Thursday , Alison Lundergan Grimes , the Democratic nominee for Senate in Kentucky , refused three times to say whether she had even voted for Mr. Obama in 2008 and 2012 , saying instead that she is “ a Clinton Democrat through and through . ”
The White House has yet to announce any campaign events Mr. Obama will hold with Democratic Senate candidates , though he has recorded get-out-the-vote phone calls , radio ads and videos for them to target selected constituencies .
The campaign of Charlie Crist , Florida ’ s Democratic candidate for governor , is now wary of inviting Mr. Obama to publicly appear with him out of concern that it would shift the focus of the race to national issues , according to a person familiar with Mr. Crist ’ s campaign strategy .
A recent Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Annenberg survey found that an endorsement from Mr. Obama would leave a more negative view of a congressional or Senate candidate , with 38 % saying they would see a candidate less favorably , compared with just 28 % who would have a more favorable view after a presidential endorsement .
Findings like those are one reason that Republicans say they welcome Mr. Obama ’ s just-announced campaign stop with Connecticut Gov . Dannel Malloy . A Malloy spokesman said the governor is happy to stand with the president and discuss shared views on issues like the minimum wage and gun laws .
Democratic Party leaders say Mr. Obama can play an important role in the campaign . Each of the three states with the highest concentration of competitive House races—New York , California and Illinois—is friendly Obama territory , Mr. Israel said .
Still , White House officials say Mr. Obama wants to help Democrats in the weeks before the Nov. 4 election , even if that means staying away from them .
Last week , after Mr. Obama said that while he isn ’ t on the ballot this November , his policies are , Republican Senate candidates rushed to produce ads replaying the remark . At Thursday ’ s fundraiser at Ms. Paltrow ’ s house , Mr. Obama tweaked the comment , saying instead “ our values ” and “ our ideals ” are on the ballot .
Many presidents have seen a similar downgrade . Republicans distanced themselves from George W. Bush in 2006 as his popularity fell over the Iraq war . “ There are always places where the incumbent president just isn ’ t popular , ” said Steve Elmendorf , a Democratic strategist .
In the absence of campaign rallies this cycle , Mr. Obama has maintained a busy fundraising schedule , headlined 58 events so far this year , with another on tap Saturday . That is comparable to his 2010 schedule , said Brendan Doherty , an associate professor of political science at the U.S . Naval Academy who compiles presidential-fundraising data .
David Winston , a Republican strategist , said the White House has a long-term interest in demonstrating that Mr. Obama still has some political capital .
“ If there was a sense that he was in a situation where he couldn ’ t help any Democratic candidate , that ’ s just not a good setup for his last two years , ” Mr. Winston said .
content_original:
At a rally for Democratic candidates filled with blistering attacks on Republicans, President Barack Obama trotted out lines from his successful 2008 campaign. “Are you fired up?” he asked. “Are you ready to go?” The crowd at a Philadelphia park, stretched out to the parking lot, chanted “Yes we can!”

That was Oct. 10, 2010. Four years later, the contrast with Mr. Obama’s role in the current midterm campaign is stark, and it underscores the limited value the Democratic Party is placing on its leader this election.

On Thursday night, Mr. Obama was in the backyard of actress Gwyneth Paltrow’s Los Angeles home, speaking to a small group of wealthy donors far from the spotlight. His tone was far different than the “Fired Up!” chant of the 2010 rally.

“Democrats have many good qualities, but a congenital disease is, A: We get depressed too easily; and B: We’re terrible at paying attention to midterm elections,” Mr. Obama said.

No cameras were allowed at Ms. Paltrow’s event. No local Democratic candidates received a presidential shout-out.

Mr. Obama’s low-key appearance at Ms. Paltrow’s home wasn’t the exception this year: He has headlined no public campaign events this election cycle, and since Labor Day he has appeared in person with only two candidates—in the Democratic states of California and Illinois. By this point four years ago, Mr. Obama had led three rallies, and in the weeks since Labor Day he had held political events with five candidates, even with an approval rating of 47%, according to the Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll at the time.

Now, with his approval at a low-water mark of 40%, according to the Journal/NBC poll, the president has been relegated to fundraising and small, targeted photo-ops like one he did Thursday when he dropped by the Los Angeles campaign office of House candidate Ted Lieu.

Rep. Steve Israel of New York, the chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said he hoped Mr. Obama’s appearance with Mr. Lieu was “a preview of similar engagements by the president.”

“We’d love to see more of that,” Mr. Israel said.

The president’s campaign slate will pick up in coming weeks—the White House said Mr. Obama would appear at a Connecticut rally next week. But in some ways, the contrast between 2010 and 2014 is only going to become more evident.

Even though the fight for control of the Senate is the year’s top battle, administration officials say much of the president’s time on the campaign trail will be spent stumping for gubernatorial and House candidates. With Mr. Obama so unpopular in most states with close Senate races this fall, Democratic candidates are putting as much distance between themselves and the president as they can. At a newspaper editorial board meeting on Thursday, Alison Lundergan Grimes, the Democratic nominee for Senate in Kentucky, refused three times to say whether she had even voted for Mr. Obama in 2008 and 2012, saying instead that she is “a Clinton Democrat through and through.”

President Obama with, from left, California House candidate Ted Lieu and Rep. Steve Israel (D., N.Y.) at a Democratic campaign office in Los Angeles on Thursday. AFP/Getty Images

The White House has yet to announce any campaign events Mr. Obama will hold with Democratic Senate candidates, though he has recorded get-out-the-vote phone calls, radio ads and videos for them to target selected constituencies.

The campaign of Charlie Crist, Florida’s Democratic candidate for governor, is now wary of inviting Mr. Obama to publicly appear with him out of concern that it would shift the focus of the race to national issues, according to a person familiar with Mr. Crist’s campaign strategy.

A recent Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Annenberg survey found that an endorsement from Mr. Obama would leave a more negative view of a congressional or Senate candidate, with 38% saying they would see a candidate less favorably, compared with just 28% who would have a more favorable view after a presidential endorsement.

Findings like those are one reason that Republicans say they welcome Mr. Obama’s just-announced campaign stop with Connecticut Gov. Dannel Malloy. A Malloy spokesman said the governor is happy to stand with the president and discuss shared views on issues like the minimum wage and gun laws.

Democratic Party leaders say Mr. Obama can play an important role in the campaign. Each of the three states with the highest concentration of competitive House races—New York, California and Illinois—is friendly Obama territory, Mr. Israel said.

Still, White House officials say Mr. Obama wants to help Democrats in the weeks before the Nov. 4 election, even if that means staying away from them.

Last week, after Mr. Obama said that while he isn’t on the ballot this November, his policies are, Republican Senate candidates rushed to produce ads replaying the remark. At Thursday’s fundraiser at Ms. Paltrow’s house, Mr. Obama tweaked the comment, saying instead “our values” and “our ideals” are on the ballot.

Many presidents have seen a similar downgrade. Republicans distanced themselves from George W. Bush in 2006 as his popularity fell over the Iraq war. “There are always places where the incumbent president just isn’t popular,” said Steve Elmendorf, a Democratic strategist.

In the absence of campaign rallies this cycle, Mr. Obama has maintained a busy fundraising schedule, headlined 58 events so far this year, with another on tap Saturday. That is comparable to his 2010 schedule, said Brendan Doherty, an associate professor of political science at the U.S. Naval Academy who compiles presidential-fundraising data.

David Winston, a Republican strategist, said the White House has a long-term interest in demonstrating that Mr. Obama still has some political capital.

“If there was a sense that he was in a situation where he couldn’t help any Democratic candidate, that’s just not a good setup for his last two years,” Mr. Winston said.

Write to Carol E. Lee at carol.lee@wsj.com and Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.com
